items.title: RISDSummer Program
items.subTitle: Print and Image: Art as Activism; Visual and Critical Language; Exploration in Design
items.description: After 3 years of Zero-COVID policies, general enthusiasm in China has been lower than ever. Mental health has become an even greater issue the world over. To chip away at these issues and to pursue my dreams of making everyone happier, I created this poster in Chinese and erected it in 798 Art Zone, an art and cultural landmark in Beijing. This is an interactive poster. Before you open it it simply says “living in this world, it’s all about laughing at yourself and smiling to others; If you are not having a happy day, please open this.” When the viewer finally opens it, they see a joke. When I put it up, I was shocked that almost everyone who walked by took a few minutes to read it. The smile that they put up on their faces seem to indicate their pleasure.

items.title: Personal Logo
items.description: This is a personal logo that I designed for myself. It is designed in Graffiti style. I included Chinese elements, such as three dragon figures that are colored in blue, purple, and yellow. One old Chinese folktale tells of a fish swimming against the current and up a waterfall, transforming into a dragon when it reaches the top of the mountain. This story motivates me to always believe in myself and try to overcome difficulties to achieve my dreams.

In the throes of hate crimes in the US, I wanted to think of a way to create discourse around the fact that violence only begets more violence and that love can bring about peace. I quoted from the famous Dr. Martin Luthur King, Jr. Just like the candle fire, life is weak and needs to be protected not to be destroyed.

Ai Weiwei, a famous Chinese artist, contributed hugely to the art society as well as to social justice issues in China. I was greatly inspired by his work. He recognized the issues within Chinese society as well as issues of the world beyond. He believes that art should be art, and so do I. I used his quotes in both English and Chinese to create this piece.
I assigned a term related to Social justice to all 26 letters of the alphabet and designed a logo for each term listed.
I experimented with different colors and saw what effects a color combination creates.
